title: 111_hr5410
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a concise summary of the section's title and its purpose. The "Accountability in Corporate Political Activity Act of 2010" allows corporations to make unlimited political disbursements from their general treasury funds, following the Supreme Court's decision in Citizens United v. FEC. This decision granted corporations the same First Amendment rights as individuals for political advocacy. Corporations should be held accountable for violating the law and the public's trust, similar to individuals, as they are currently not subject to disenfranchisement like individuals convicted of a felony in the United States. Prohibiting corporations from engaging in campaign-related activity if subject to criminal or civil sanctions. Prohibition on corporations engaging in campaign-related activity if subject to certain sanctions, including criminal or civil penalties of $1,000,000 or more under federal law. The prohibition on corporations engaging in campaign-related activity applies if they are subject to sanctions of $1,000,000 or more under federal law. The court or entity imposing the sanction can determine the period for which the prohibition applies to the corporation. If the prohibition is not applied, the court or entity must publicly explain their reasons to the Commission. Upon enactment of the Act, the Federal Election Commission will disseminate information to the public and notify each State about the prohibition on campaign-related activities by corporations as defined in the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, as amended, imposes sanctions on corporations for violations, effective immediately upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or amendment is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and its amendments will not be affected.
